Growler provided by kmweaver. Cloudy dark amber body with a small beige head. The nose is fairly sweet and lightly herbal with caramel, dark fruits and honey. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly medicinal and herbal with golden raisins, caramel and brown sugar. Medium body is a bit rough with light carbonation and an astringent finish.

(Draught)  Pours a cloudy deep golden brown body with a moderate off-white head.  Aroma of bubble gum, clove, bananas, figs, and brown sugar.  Flavor of figs, banana, clove, orange, caramel, and nuts.

Draft at the brewpub.  Aroma:  Wheat, toasted malt, yeast, banana, bubble gum, orange, cinnamon, cloves.  Some deep earthiness as it warms.  Alcohol steps up a bit as it warms.  Appearance:  Rusty brown in color and very cloudy.  Light beige head was small and foamy with good retention.  Good lacing.  Flavor:  Sweet maltiness with notes of toasted nuts, wheat, bready yeast, vanilla, raisins, banana, clove, and orange.  Alcohol is nice and warming throughout.  Sweet finish.  Palate:  Medium-full bodied.  Medium carbonation.  Alcohol warmth in back of mouth.  Overall:  I always seemed to miss this one when it went on tap at GLBC.  Not this time.  Didnt disappoint.  A little muddled and overly sweet at times, but still pretty solid.

Growler shared by kmweaver.  My notes say: sweet, thin, faint, light, sticky, sweet.  There’s some light banana and some bigger yeast notes, but overall it’s a really banal beer to drink... it’s soft and quiet, with some bready apples, honey and wheat notes, and the yeast resembles yogurt, but overall it just really doesn’t do anything for me.  Thin but chewy, a bit too sweet, missing the bock characteristics of weizen bock, and the body doesn’t help either.

Sampled at the brewery and sampled from a growler at the Columbus tasting.  Poured a rather ugly muddled mix between brown and plum colors.  The aroma was a fantastic meld of spices, yeast, all sorts of fruits including bananas, grapes, plums, some clove, and even some breadniess.  Very full palate yet super easy to drink and not much noticeable alcohol.  Good stuff indeed!!

Almost brown color, quite cloudy full tan head w/ great lacing.  Cloves, wheat, light bread, a touch of dark fruits.  Light on the tongue w/ a full creamy swallow.  Fruity front banana, clove, bread, dark fruits, a touch of alcohol.  Very nice stuff.

Growler shared at Cbus tasting number nine by Leopoldstoch. Thanks Brandon! Smelled like a banana buble gum! Taste was sweet oranges, bananas, and malts. This was a VERY easy to drink brew. Most enjoyable of the evening.

C-Bus 9 shared by shared by butters: Growler: Pours a hazy copper/red with a tan head. Aroma, wheat, yeast, some fruits, malty and sweet. Flavor, wheat, fruits, roasted notes, yeast, some tang to it, with a sweet carmelly finish. Very nice brew.

Growler, sent out of nowhere by miketd.  Thanks a ton, Mike!  Pours a murky, deep brownish-amber color; off-white head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Chewy, bananas and brown sugar and esters in the aroma; on the sweet side.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: chewy brown sugar, bananas, and dried fruits; pretty dense and excellent chewiness; some vanilla notes, but overall a bit muddled and overly sugary; I was hoping for a bit more complexity out of this; still, remains generous and drinkable.  Lengthy, vanilla and estery finish.

Poured from a growler.  Burnt red and entirely opaque appearance.  Lengthy and aroma heavy with details.  Pears, sesame seed, musty cheese and footy garlic sweat.  Hints of pine, juniper and aluminum in an earthy, bitter middle.  Dill and balsamic finish in a strange tangy burst.  Taste is less for uniqueness; stunningly simple dry wheat at first.  Apples, hay, yerba, and vanilla with a somewhat lactic tone.  Hints of quiet pineapple and aggressive cloves, predictable though authentic.  Medium bodied palate lacks depth and leaves an impression thinner than it actually is.  Finishes with cherry pits and wet wood, pulsing with rotted mossy earth and sweetness.  A dry coating unfolds slowly.  It sits a bit awkwardly on the edge;  weakly grasping the balance of sprightliness and richness that the best examples achieve with ease.  Thanks for sharing Ken!
Brown amber color with no head or lacing. Aroma is rich and fruity with light hops. Flavor has strong fruits, citrus, caramel malts, and a light alcohol tingle. Very smooth and easy to drink

Sample from Growler courtesy of weeare138. Poured a medium to deeper and cloudy amberish / brownish color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of bananas, cloves, cinnamon, citrus, wheat, and caramel. Tastes of bananas, wheat, caramel, cloves, and citrus. Nice clean finish.

Poured a murky brown amber color with a small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of banana, clove, nuts, caramel malts, and light citrus.  Taste of banana cream, clove, tart citrus fruits, toffee malts, caramel, with a dry, faintly alcoholic finish. Thanks to weeare138 for sharing this!

Thanx to Boboski for this. Poured from a growler a dark orange brew with a thinning head that laced the edge of the glass beautifully.Lots of arom coming up.Bananas and clove the most noticeable.Flavor was well balanced with banana, cloves and honey with a nice warming feeling going down.Started of slightly sour then the sweetness kicked in. Mouthfeel was medium and it finished slightly sweet and clean.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2009 Courtesy boboski, from a growler. This poured a sunset orange color with a thin white head. It smelled of bananas, cloves, some cinnamon, wheat, and some sweet citrus fruit. The flavor was somewhat tart and sweet from the fruits with the wheat characters coming through. The sweet flavors really come through and is nicely carbonated, and leads to a crisp clean finish. The flavors were really well balanced and masked the alcohol very well. The mouthfeel was lowly carbonated with a thick and sweet flavor to it that lends to being very easy to drink. Really well done for this style. A pleasure to be able to try this.

Growler courtesy of crizay: Pours a hazy copper amber with full, nicely-lacing off-white head.  Aroma has some light sulfur and tart notes along with a touch of clove and bready German yeast.  Body starts fairly full with an authentic, doughy wheaty sweetness, some banana and clove flavor toward a bready German yeasty finish.  Nice authenticity and good drinkability, a good weizenbock and surprising made in America, but not quite Aventinus.

From bomber courtesy boboski.  Pours a muddy caramel-brown with a thin light khaki head that quickly moves to the edges of the glass.  Sweet and fruity with a healthy dose of phenols reminiscent of an overripe banana.  Lighter on the palate than expected, and well-supported by the carbonation.  Light sugarcane taste with dates and plums in the middle.  The smooth finish is slightly sour and contrasts the overall sweetness nicely.  The sweetness never overpowers.  A fine brew.

A thin off-white head recedes slowly, not fully; fat, sparse dot lacing remains. Murky, multi-hued ambers and hot oranges swirl amongst each other in a dense body flooded with immobile, fine carbonation. Banana and clove are evident first, alone in a soft but full aroma. Banana is fresh and overripe and joined soon after by passionfruit, plum and vanilla. Herbs and toasty malt provide an earthy background. Yeast is fully attenuated and sugars are mild. Alcohol is extremely well masked. Simple but effective employment of malt and yeast. An expansion of seriously sweet banana and multiple esters becomes even sweeter upon first sip. Bitterness is soft and definitely must be sought out. Plum provides a sugary note with hints of herbs and earth. The flavor is very highly sweet, but is admirable and doesnt lead to a sticky or cloying finish; the finale of each sip is actually quite clean and attempts a crisp turnaround. The finish is smooth, balanced within the typicalities of the style, lengthy and sublime. The mouthfeel is softly and very lowly carbonated, thick and gooey, extremely easy to drink. Awesome.

Courtesy boboski. Pours a very hazy, murky amber, touches of auburn.  Head is non-existant.  Aroma is full on ripe bananas and cloves, pleasant grains, some raisins.  Flavor was mellow and well rounded, the wheat presence does shine a bit.  The sweetness is there, but is not over the top r off putting in any way.

Courtesy boboski.  Pours a cloudy, cool looking, dark orange/red with a tiny little white head.  Smells of mild banana, clove, some sweet tart fruits, wheat, cinnamon and malts.  The flavor is slightly tart, mildly carbonated, with a profound wheat presence.  Seemingly more weizen than bock.  Get some sweet fruits right off the bat, then turns into banana and wheat characters.  Nicely donr for this style.  Balanced well and enjoyable.

Courtesy boboski. Growler. Hazy amber/brown/burnt orange. Small layer of off white carbonation reduces itself to a ring. Aroma of pungent past ripe fruit, banana, clove like spice, light floral sweetness, and toasted grains. Flavor adds whole grain bread, subtle caramel, roasted nuts, and airy yeast. Medium/full body. A bit low on carbonation- the growler was opened a few hours ago and has been kept closed when not being poured, but likely still the cause. Not a big deal, though. Excellent weizenbock.

Courtesy boboski.  Growler.  Cloudy, murky, dark orange-amber body.  Minimal, wispy film at the top with a small, off-white edge.  Tiny, organic looking snakes of lacing that droop their way back to the body slowly.  The aroma shows big, sweet bananas that are just past the point of ideal ripeness.  Wafts of softened clove and nutmeg accompany the fruity sweetness.  The flavor has a base of mashed banana puree.  The spiciness is very soft and subtle on the palate.  Theres a single drop of agave nectar sweetness, and maybe even some subtle hints of golden raisons.  The body is just on the heavy side of medium.  Very smooth, almost silky on the tongue.  The finish is short, clean, and ever so slightly sticky.  Really nice brew.

Growler from miketd - thanks!  Cloudy brown pour with a small head.  Big, sweet aroma thats dominated by banana, fresh berries, spice, and sweet bready malts.  Flavor is very sweet and fruity with lots of banana, some berries, sweet grains, spices, and summer fruits.  Sticky and tingly - a really nice W-Bock.  Nice example of one of my favorite styles.

This beer is near perfect.  Very nice gold color with a light cream color head.  Full bodied with an earthy grain flavor.  Great malty smoothness with just enough of a sweet taste to make it interesting.  Malty and sweet at the finish.  Incredible beer for me.

Doughy citrus, plums, raisins and dates all figure prominently in the enticing aroma.  Opaque cloudy tan-copper body is topped by a low, fine bubbled, off white head that lasts well and leaves some sudsy lacing.  Lightly alcoholic dark fruit flavour with plenty of sugary sweet malt character.  Medium full body with moderate carbonation.  Sampled at GABF 2005.
GABF 05.  Pours a cloudy amber with an aroma of bubblegum and banana.   Flavor follows suit, but its more like a Belgium version of a hefe than a German.  Palate coats.  Outstanding beer.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Sampled @ GABF- Pours a murky dark purple, slightly brown color, nice sized white head. Aroma is pleasent, fruit and malts combine very well to please the nose. Flavor is smooth, banana clove, sinnamon, chocolate notes, clean dry finish. Alcohol is hidden quite well Nice brew!

Muddy brown, covered by an enormous off-white foamy and eternal head. Charming aventinus like toasted malt and identifiable biscuitiness is taken aback by this surprisingly efficient yeast bringing forth pure doughy, banana, grapey and cloves glory. Remarkable flavours integration, whereas the chocolate meet the cloves into an herbal fashion and to make any Chefs envy. Body is medium in size, creamy, ample and mineral, showing the wheat a perfect ground to work in. Exquisite balance, might be as good as Aventinus.

GABF 2005 and rating #2112 !  I see the works of gifted hands, that grace this strange and wondrous land. - Rush, 2112; Oracle: The Dream 
Hazed yellow hue with a nice frothy head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of banana and clove esters, caramelized and smoked malting, a bit of wheaty and grainy notes, and even a bit meaty. The taste follows suit with good working of both the weizen and bock character. More weizen up front with the fruity and spice nature before a smoky and sweet finish. The feel is smooth and creamy. One hell of a brew and one of my favorites at the fest.

GABF 2005.

Body is hazy dark yellow.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel), with notes of banana, clove, and vanilla.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic.
Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter.

Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Came far from blowing me away, but this was a nice step up in all aspects from Flying Dogs.  Solid malty and estery nose with good flavor balance and mouthfeel.

This beer is excellent.  It has a gorgeous golden wheat color, with a beautiful foamy golden head.  The head is creamy and pillowy on the palate.  The body of the beer is thick and feels great on the palate, as well.  The beer smells strong of banana, and spice, with wheat.  The taste goes down smooth, and is very sweet but with just enough wheat and malt flavoring to remind you that it is beer.  The aftertaste is creamy, and sweet.  What a great beer.  It would be tough to drink many of these.  But if you are going to drink a beer that is sweet, ... make sure its this one.

Cloudy dark amber w/ soft, frothy tan foam. Toasty aroma of banana, caramel, wheat & cloves w/ a hint of licorice & smoke. Soft, creamy feel.  Delicious flavour of banana cream pie w/ a toasted, slightly burnt crust drizzled in caramel. Finish leaves warm, spicy notes.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2007 The desription says it all, it really does. The color is the inside of a plum, the scent is spicy, cloves and banana. Guess what it tastes like, cloves and banana. Creamy as all hell, the lower levels of carbonation do this beer justice. Its puts me into a beer nirvana that cannot be explained. Im in love with this beer. Just a great collaboration of spiciness, banana, and a creamy mouthfeel. Its been 3 years and is staying my only 5.

On tap at Great Lakes.  Hazy caramel color, lightly reddish, with little head.  Bananas and caramel dominate the strong nose, with a bit of strawberry eddying in the background.  Smooth, lightly smoky/tarry, quite malty, burnt caramel and rum-soaked bananas, alcohol well-hidden, fairly dry for the style....outstanding.

Cloudy Deep orange color.  Pint was too full for a head, really.  But a vigorous swirl made a foamy pillow form on top.  Very rich nose of wheat and spice.  Full bodied and sweet, almost.  Quite yeasty and accented with a touch of spice.  Malty finish.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2005 i had this beer on tap earlier tonight at great lakes brewing. the nose was mighty inviting with its spicy banana aroma. nice lacy legs left on the side of the glass. good, full beer id recommend thats very drinkable!
on tap GABF 02:  Big clove and slight banana aroma rising out of muddy orange liquid.  full bodied, starts and ends sweet.  Great brew with a good wheat character.
GABF 2002: Cloudy, dark yellow/light orange.  Nice yeasty/banana aroma.  Smooth banana flavour.  Surprisngly light bodied despite its strength.  Very good.
10/6/02 - at their pub.  Huge banana/spice aroma that carries over into the flavor.  Color is copper/golden and very cloudy.  delicious.
GABF 2002: Cloudy copper color.  Lemony zesty aroma.  Candyish bubblegum flavor.  Strong and rich, almost cloying.
